div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: A MONUMENTAL WORK.*
div.p:
The fifth volume of "The World's History,"
which is edited by Dr. H. F. Helmholt, and to
which an introductory essay by the Right Hon.
James Bryce has been attached, has now made
its somewhat belated appearance. It deals
with South-Eastern and Eastern Europe, and,
in the brief review which it is only possible to
give here, can be said to maintain the high
level of the preceding tomes. As we ander
stand that arrangements have already been
made for bringing "The World's History" up
to date, criticism may be deferred until the
new volumes appear. But in the meantime
we might record our appreciation, in general
terms, of the care with which the present
volume has been prepared.

The History of South-Eastern and Eastern
Europe deals in a measure with one of the most
interesting periods of Western civilisation. The
influence of Hellenism was so pronounced that
its relation to the gradual development of the
standards of Oriental art and culture ne-
cessarily present a most absorbing study. The
founding of Alexander's Empire gave it op-
portunities for expansion which, if not parti-
cularly impressive, were at least unfettered.
Alexandria and the revival of Babylon were
but stages in its evolution; and, although
Hellenism could regard these centres as in-
tellectual possessions, they were as much the
outcome of an accidental condition as they
were the product of an intellectual conquest.
Gradually, however, the union between the East
and the West brought about the destruction
of the very purpose which it had been intended
to set up. At a distance Hellenism assumed
qualities which it was found incapable of pre-
serving in the press of its domestic environ-
ment, and the union of the East and the West
fell quickly and as marvellously as it had been
drawn together.

It is with this subject. The Influence of Hel-
lenism after Alexander the Great, that the
present volume opens, while other important
phases in the history of the world that are
discussed refer to the Story of Turkey in
Europe and Armenia, to the Position of the
Albanians, to Bohemia before its union with
Austria, to that avalanche of barbarians that
gave rise to the Danube peoples, and to Eas-
tern Europe. Each chapter is the work of a
distinguished master and presents an elaborate
and scholarly survey of the changes which
have taken place in the growth of the world.

div.head: Polloe Budget
div.p:
During the last twenty-four hours 6 thefts
15 misdemeanours and 53 petty offences have
been recorded in Cairo.

div.head: Hashish Seizure.
div.p:
The Coast Guards Administration reports
that the patrof operating in the Western
Desert have seized 6 sacks of hashish contain.
ing 170 kilos.

div.head: The Sultan's Anniversary.
div.p:
To-day being the 68th anniversary of the
Sultan's birthday, ceremonies will take place
at Constantinople and throughout Turkey.
The day will be observed as a general holiday.

div.head: Death From Drink.
div.p:
A native found on the pavement in a terrible
state of intoxication at rue Haminam-Baba,
Saida, was conveyed by the police to the
hospital, but expired from aleobolic poisoning
on arrival.

div.head: White Slave Traffic.
div.p:
At the request of the French Consulate the
Cairo City police paida visit yesterday to No.
15 Rue do Telephone where they arrested a
young girl under age, suspected of being on
the premises for immoral purposes.

div.head: Public Works Ministry.
div.p:
By a Ministerial decree of the 18th instant
Abdel Megid Effendi Omar, Assistant Engin-
eer of the 4th Circle of Irrigation, Fayoum,
will be transferred to the Ministry of Public
Instruction, as from 4th September.

div.head: New Creek University.
div.p:
A Telegram from Athens announces that
after long negotiations the Russian Govern-
inent has restored to Greece the fortune left
some years ago by Dompoli, a rich Greek
who died in Russia. This fortune amounts to
several millions of francs and will be devoted
by the Government to the establishment of a
University which will bear the name of the
deceased.

div.head: European Press Syndicate.
div.p:
A meeting of European journalists of Cairo
took place on Sunday evening at the Con-
tinental Hotel Cairo, for the purpose of consti-
tuting the above syndicate, and approving the
statutes elaborated by the provisional commit-
tee. The committee for the first year is com-
posed of M.M. Braun Caravia, Colrat, Derroja,
di Collalto, Kastner, Rudy, and Verdier.

div.head: Australla And The Suez Canal
div.p:
Mr. Henniker Heaton, M.P., in a letter to
the "Sydney Morning Herald," attacks the
British Government in respect to the profit
which it derives from the Suez Canal shares as
unfairly handicapping Australian trades.
The writer says that he will introduce a mo-
tion in the House of Commons to the effect
that Great Britain should be content with a
10 per cent. dividend, returning the surplus to
the owners of British ships passing through the
Canal doring the twelve months preceding each
declaration of dividend. Mr. Henniker Heaton
adds that he will use his influence to induce
the Suez Canal Company to adopt a similar
policy.

div.head: A Quay Accident.
div.p:
This morning, shortly after ten o'clock, an
arabeah with a pair of horses was backing
towards the edge of quay No. 30, where the
P and O. SS. "Caledonia," arrived this
morning, is moored, and going too far
the back part of the carriage was jerked
over the side of the quay, and, the horses
being unable to recover themselves, both
the arabeah and the animals were thrown
into. the water and sank immediately. Happily
the arbagi was able to jump off his box just as
the carriage was going over and so was saved.
After an hour's hard work carriage and horses
were dragged up by an anchor hualed by a
large number of native workmen.

div.head: ATLANTIC STEAMSHIP COMPETITION.
div.p:
The cutting of Atlantic cabin rates, thus
far confined to eastbound traffic, will shortly
be extended to westbound passenger traftic, as is
shown by the circular issued by the White Star
Line to the effect that the minimum cabin fares
hy these steamersâ€"the Adriatic, Oceanic, Ma-
jestic, Teutonic, Baltic, Cedric, Celtic, and
Arabic--will on and after November 1 he re-
duced by £7 10s., or £5 10s. below the ordinary
winter rates which will have automatically come
into force on that date, while the rates by the
Republic and Cymric will be Â£3 and Â£1 respec
tively below winter rates. The American Line
have also informed the agents that the rates by
their steamers sailing for Southampton will on
November 1 be reduced to ten guineas, which
is £1 10s. below ordinary winter rates. As a
result the Canadian lines are considering the
question of following suit. The Cunard Line
have not issued their winter rates, and will not
state what they are likely todo, but it is pretty
certain that they will fix fares at a similar level
ty those of their competitors. The feeling is
that all other lines will follow these rates both
in the New York and Boston trade, and that
there is every prospect of a rate aware this
winter. It is considered that the position is
extremely grave, as big â€œcutsâ€ into first cabin
fares bring them almost as low as second cabin
fares, and if these are adjusted accordingly
third-class fares will also have to be reduced.

div.head: Cheap Gas from Common Fuels
div.p:
for Engines, Manufacturing, Furnaces, Pump
ing, Irrigation, Incandescent Lighting and
Generation of Electricity. Lane's Producers are
available for Land, River or Ocean Service.

div.head: THE "AMIRAL MIAOULIS."
PORT-SAID, Sunday.
div.p:
To-morrow the Greek training ship "Amiral
Miaoulis" will leave, after having spent eight
days at this port. During the week the
Greek community have been making merry in
honour of the officers and cadets, every day
having been most enjoyably spent: On the
night of the arrival of the "Amiral Miaoulis"
there was a large banquet at the Casino, at
which most of the Greek community were pre-
sent ; complimentary speeches were made and
the usual formalities gone through. On Sunday
night the Greek Consul and his wife entertained
a large party to dinner ot the Eastern Ex-
change. Included in the party were Mr. M. G.
Coroni, president of the Greek community
and his wife, Dr. Emiris and many others.
The festivities during the remainder of the
week included a garden party given by
Mouheb Pasha at which there was a large
attendance, and a tea and dance on board
ship, dancing being kept up till early morn-
ing. There was also an "At home" and small
dance at the Casino, at which all spent a very
enjoyable time. To-night there is to be an
"At home" and dance at the International
Club, to be followed by a dinner.

div.head: The Italian Fete.
div.p:
On Thursday night there was a concert at
the Lesseps Gardens. The grounds were illumin-
ated to perfection and a large crowd gathered
to listen to the Margherita band which was in
attendance. Among those present were Count
and Countess Mancinelli Scott Mouhel Pasha,
and the Greek Consul. On Friday morning
Count Mancinelli Scotti held a reception at the
Consulate, and at 6 p.m. there was the usual
meeting at the Eldorado at which there was a
large attendance. Mr. A. Vailati, and Mr. A.
Copolla and others delivered speeches which
were well received. After the meeting the
Casino was visited, and long before 8 p.m. it
was impossible to obtain a seat. The building
and grounds were -lit up with thousands of
electric lamps and presented a very fine sight.
At 9 p.m. there was a large dinner of over 150
covers, and during and after dinner the
"Margherita" performed.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p:
A Council of Ministers was held yesterday,
and decided upon the following resolutions:--
To erect a telephone line to Fayoum.
To appropriate land at Mansoura for the
purpose of enlarging the Station.
To make a new road in the village of Aja,
Dakahlia.

To exempt the tax on the lands bought by
the American Nile Company at Port Said for
the purpose of building a school.

div.head: ST. FRANCOIS XAVIER COLLEGE.
div.p:
On Tuesday the first of October the classes
of the St. Francois Xavier College will be re
sumed under the new director, Mr. R P. Cotet,
who formerly directed the College of the Holy
Pamily at Cairo. Mr. Cotet is one of the
most respected Jesuits of the colony and is
regarded by all with confidence and sympathy.
Lord Cromer had occasion to express to him
his esteem for his work and character and in
Cairo he was deservedly popular in his sphere
of life. Withont suppressing the classies, the
basis upon which all education must be carried
on to be complete, special attention will be
given to modern languages and commercial
education.

div.head: RED SEA SALT FOR THE FAR EAST.
div.p:
A German export journal having published
an article on the advantage to be derived from
the export of fish (particularly salmon, with
which the River Amur and its tributaries
abound) from the Far East to Europe, the
question of a return freight has given rise, the
"Financier" states, to the suggestion that the
deposits of rock salt to be found in Turkey
might very well be turned to aecount, It is
added that the salmon of the Amur, owing to
its high quality, has won a favoarable position
on the St. Petersburg, London, and Hamburg
markets, though hitherto only in small quan-
tities. The chief obstacle to the disposal of large
quantities of Amur River salmon, independent
of the great distance and the locking-up of the
Nikolaiefisk port with ice, is the absence of
rock-salt on the spot, which is so requisite for
keeping fish during long voyages.

Up till recently the demand for salt in the
Far East was mostly satisfied by supplies, from
Hamburg, of German origin, and the firms
engaged in this trade so monopolised it as to
be able to gradually raise the price to such a
point as to actually interfere with their own
trade. This situation prompted the Russischer
Import Combination to seek other sources of
rock-salt supply for the Far East ; and this firm
has fixed its affections on the deposits to be
found on the Turkish shore of the Red Sea. It
has already made an arrangement with the
chief authority--the "Dette Publique," in
Constantinople. It is further proposed to
develop the exchange of goods between Turkey
and the Far East by bringing timber home to
Turkey in exchange for the salt.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p:
The handicap for to-morrow's regatta is the
same as last week.

Rating Class & Class I.--Course A. Class
II.--Course Q.

div.head: THE OLIVE CROP.
div.p:
Some heavy rain fell at Nicosia and in some
parts of the plain last week. It was of some
use in freshening up the parched vegetation,
in softening the baked ground, and in making
the dusty roads less unpleasant. Fortunately
it came just before cotton. picking had become
general. On Troodos the storm lasted through
the greater part of two days, and has been
followed by very enjoyable weather.

An all-day cricket match, Civilians v.
Military took place on Troodos on the 14th
inst. After a closely fought game the match
was won by the former who also scored a
victory in the first match earlier in the season.
Cold collation was provided for the players by
the Civilians.

The olive crop is now being gathered in the
low-lying pasts of the Island. The gathering in
the higherlands is generally fixed to begin
towards the end of September. Under the Olive
Law the date for gathering this fruit is annually
fixed by the District Commissioners. This
provides a safeguard against thefts from the
trees, which formerly were wholesale among
the villagers as soon as the olives approached
in any degree the point of maturity. Under
this Law fresh olives may not be exposed for
sale prior to the date fixed, and from that date
the owners are enabled to take the necessary
precautions to protect their produce.
The pomegranate crop is reported to be less
than last year, and the prices are accordingly
high.

The Asbestos Company is steadily at work
on Mt. Troodos and the little settlement there
presents a busy scene. Should the quarries
prove as extensive as is anticipated, and of the
desired quality, the industry should afford
profitable employment to a considerable num-
ber ofmen and women. That the existence of
asbestos was known to the ancients and was an
object of commerce in Cyprus in olden times is
a well known fact. Various writers refer to it
and Mons. Gaudry mentions that one use to
which it was put was in the manufacture of
shrouds or sacks for princes and persons of
high degree. The bodies were enclosed in
them and burnt the sacks remaining intact
and preserving the calcined remains of the
deceased.

A scheme is on foot in the Limassol district
for constructing a single line of railway from
Limassol to Troodos, passing through several
of the vine villages of that locality.
Much loss is annually caused to caroub tree
owners by the depredations of rats. Efforts
have from time to time been made for their
extermination, but with small results. A move-
ment of a practical kind has now been started
in the Larnaca district which promises well. A
society has been formed with the object of
collecting funds for the purchase of rats, and
also to encourage the planting of caroub trees.
The work is receiving excellent local support,
and already a considerable sum has been col-
lected among different villages, so that opera-
tions can be begun without delay. Experiments
are also to be made with various rat poisons
to discover an effective remedy against this
serious pest.

General Bullock, attended by Lieut. Fraser,
A.D.C., visited various places of interest in the
Island, after having inspected the detachment
and military arrangements on Troodos. He left
for Egypt by last week's mail.

Mr. Douglas King Harman, a naval cadet,
ard second son of His Excellency the High
Commissioner, who has been spending his
summer vacation with his pareuts on T'roodos,
has been unwell and has been removed to the
Nicosia Hospital, Lady King Harman has
returned to Nicosia to be near him.

Much regret is felt among the English com-
munity at the sad death of Canon Marriott, of
St. Georges Colleges, Jerusalem. He was in
Cyprus only last spring with Bishop Blyth, and
made many friends. Much sympathy is felt for
his widow in her bereavement.

Mr. Arthur Page, of the Chief Secretariat,
has been appointed Commissioner of Kyreina,
in succession to Major Tankerville Chamber-
layne who is shortly retiring.

Turkey has now reduced the quarantine on
arrivals from 4 days to 2 days, so we shall
probably see a falling oft in the number ot
vessels performing voluntary quarantine at
Larnaca.

An English mining engineer has this sum-
mer been placed in charge of the Lymni
copper mines, and four Italian miners recently
came over to work there.

div.head: JAPANESE BATTLESHIPS.
div.p:
The Japanese battleship "Tsukuba" came
out of the Canal this forenoon towed by a Canal
Company's tug. The second battleship "Chitose"
is now in the Canal, and both ships will proceed
to Japan after coaling at Suez.

div.head: Mail Steamer Aground.
div.p:
Yesterday afternoon the Deutsche Ost Afrika
mail steamer "Margkraf" while on her way out
of the Canal, grounded near 152 Kilo station,
and stopped the straffic till 10 p.m, when she
was refloated without assistance, by the rising
of the tide.

div.head: The "Alisa Craig."
div.p:
The SS. "Ailsa Craig" which sailed from
Suez last Saturday in ballast is bound to Salif,
where from she will take a full cargo of salt for
Calcutta.

div.head:
NEW ROUMANIAN
STEAMSHIP.
THE S.S. "DACIA."
div.p:
The newly built steamship "Dacia" which
re-inaugurates the express services between
Constanza, Constantinople, and Alexandria
arrived arrived here yesterday morning and
will start on the return journey this after-
noon. Yesterday afternoon, by invitation
of Messrs Wm. H. Muller and Company,
we had the opportunity of personally
inspecting this splendid vessel, and can em-
phatically endorse the laudatory descrip-
tions which we previously received of her.
The "Dacia" was built by order of the Service
Maritime Roumain in the ship-building yards
of the Loire at St. Nazaire, which she left on
the 10th of July last. Her length is 103,260
mm., breadth 12,770mm., draught 5.40 metres,
and with engines of 700 horse-power she. has
a speed of 18-knots per hour. Her tonnage is
4,505. Improving upon the earlier built boats
of.thig service, the promenade deck has been
considerably enlarged, and the reading, smok-
ing, and music saloons are also more capacious.
e dining saloon, as well as the saloons just
mentioned, is most luxuriously furnished and
with a height of about 12 feet and a liberal
supply of electric fans the ventilation is
perfect ; this saloon can seat 85 passengers in
comfort. The state cabins, of which there are
four, are magnificently upholstered and attach-
ed to them are bathrooms, fitted with hot and
cold water, and lavatories with up-to-date
sanitary arrangements. The first class accom-
modation is 108 and the cabins are most roomy,
well-ventilated and furnished, while each is
provided with an electric fan. Two cabins of the
first class are specially reserved for Moslem
ladies and specially furnished with a view to
providing them with luxuries of the harem.

The second class of the vessel is equally as
comfortable as the first, and second-class
pabsengers will have the same advantages
of electric lights, fans, heaters etc. A
special feature of the ship is the vibratory
chair on the promenade deck, which is
supposed to be an infallible cure for sea-sick-
ness. The vessel is fitted with the Popp
wireless telegraphic system, by which messages
can be transmitted some 300 miles.

A large number of people visited the ship
yesterday afternoon,including Mustapha Pasha
Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, and expressions
of admiration were heard on all sides.

div.head: DEPARTURE POSTPONED.
div.p: Aden, September 19.

Advices from Hodeida state that the des-
patch of the commission from Mecca to the
Imam (mentioned in my last letter) has been
postponed. The reasons are not known, but if
rumour is to be believed the despatch of the
commission is considered unnecessary and like-
ly to be as fruitless as the others. The latest
reports from Yemen state that there has been
again some trouble amongst the Arab soldiers
in Zabeed. An affray took place between them
and three or foar casualities have occurred.

div.head: GRAND WRESTLING CHAMPIONSHIP.
div.p:
Yesterday evening the first scene in the wrestling championship, organised by the journal "Les Pyramides," took place before a large audience at the Eldorado theatre. The varions bouts were brilliantly contested and the spectators were lavish in their applause of
the competitors. The 12 champions made an
excellent impression on their introduction.
The encounter between Ruggero, champion
ot Italy, and Pontelli was the occasion of
tremendons excitement, and in the ardour
of combat a good deal of the stage decoration was broken, and Ruggero with. terrific
force sent his adversary into the orchestra.
The concert which preceeded the wrestling
was a great success, Mademoiselle Va-
lintine and the famous imitator Carallieri
being well received. This evening the second
round in the championship will, take place.
Concert commences at 9.30.
Results of 1st Round:--
1st Contest Furny beat Ajax in 16 minutes.
2nd Contest Annoni beat Van Kouperus in 23 minutes.

3rd Contest Ruggero beat Pontelli in 14
minutes.

div.head: RIFLE SHOOTING.
div.p:
A match between teams from the 1st Royal
Dublin Fusiliers and the British Rifle Club
(Alex.) will be shot off next Thursday 26th
inst., starting at 2.30 pm.

div.head:
A.S.C.
NOTICE TO GOLFERS.
div.p:
Owing to a polo match taking place on
Saturday next, the course of the Alexandria
Sporting Club will be closed to golfers on that
day.

div.head: A.S.C.
AMATEUR RACE MEETING.
div.p:
Owners are informed that entries for the
amateur race meeting will close on Tuesday
the 1st of October next at 6 p.m.
In accordance with the generally expressed
desire, the weights in the 3rd Race Open Plate
and 5th Race Pony Plate will be raised from
10.7 to 11 stone.

div.head:
THE HAMIDIEH
SCHOOL OF ENDUSFTRY.
div.p:
The ceremony of the inauguration of the
Hamidieh School of Industry and Commerce,
and of the Hamidieh Hospital was a grand and
solemn function, having been celebrated by
Imperial order. The inception of this enter-
prise is due to the initiative and progressive
spirit of our Governor General, Khalil Pasha,
and, indeed, this is but one of many enterprises
of an analogous nature with which he has distin-
guished his career during his tenure of office
in other vilayets of the Empire. This last
however, is the most noteworthy, and eclipses
his former achievements in its colossal propor.
tions. With a wise sense of the fitness of things
his Excellency conceived the happy idea of
commemorating the foundation of these institu-
tions, and christening them with the imperial
name on the 30th anniversary of His Majesty's
accession to the throne ; and levied a head tax
of two mejidies on every Ottoman subject
leaving or entering this town. The collection
of this tax and its manner of utilisation seem
to have been made with creditable regularity.
Over £27,000 have been collected and spent
on this memorial establishment and the active
manner in which the work has been, and is still
being, pushed, despite the scarcity of labourers.
and masons, proves that the wages have been
settled so far with the utmost punctuality.
The choice of the spot is another testimony to
the sagacity of the Governor General. For such
establishments a vast tract of land, salubrious
and not very far from the town, was necessary,
and with shrewd insight Khalil Pasha has sol-
ved the problem of both cost and proximty. To
the South West of Beyrout, and not very far
from the centre thereof lies a vast stretch of
sand dunes that extend to the sea. So far these
sandy lands have been neglected, and the
ownership thereof was in some cases ambiguous
and not very clearly asserted out of a sense of
neglect attaching as a rule to things of little
value. Now Khalil Pasha has appropriated
out of this land about 35,842 pics for the
erection of the imperial monuments. Some
people have criticised what they described a
high handed act but apart from the appro-
priateness of making a generous contribution
from the people towards the commemoration
of a happy and unique event in a sovereign's
reign. His Excellency has created a beautiful
quarter where there was nothing but a
sandy desert. The gain to the neighboring
lands is very considerable and far outweighs
the nominal loss of the part appropriated
Furthermore the Vali has caused the electric
tramway to include in its network of lines one
extending to the said quarter, and already
around the imposing group of buildings, partly
achieved and partly on the way to completion,
a number of fine houses have sprung up and,
owing to the additional advantage of a very
salubrious climate, this quarter is destined to
become very popular. The spot is very elevated
and from every point the sea and the hills are
dominated. On the crest ot this sandy mound
the group of commemorative buildings was
planned to be erected, and the following have
already been practically completed. The first is
the direction, a two storeyed building of fine
hewn Lattakia stone, with a facade of 44 meters
and a depth of 30 meters. Two vast halls, 15
rooms and several porches constitute the
ground floor. The upper floor consists of a vast
reception hall, 30 meters long and 7 meters
wide, with a fine colonnade of marble, and two
smaller halls, three balconies and ten rooms.

The second is the establishment proper, and
has an equal front and width of 60 metets.
It is also two storeyed and the ground floor
is composed of 14 study rooms, workshops,
and studios, as well as five porches, while the
upper storey consists of five halls and fifteen
dormitories. The third is the refectory with
a front of 44 meters by a width of 30 metres,
and a magnificent colonnade of 48 columns,
with a seating capacity for sixty persons.
Adjoining the refectory is a culinary establish-
ment with several rooms and baths, and a
front of 44 meters by a width of 16 meters.

The fourth of the principal group is a mos-
que 28 meters long by 18 wide. The fifth
constitutes in fact a lesser group of three
buildings representing one hospital for women
18 meters long by 20 wide, already finished,
and two others of 47 meters length by 10
width, each for men, and expected to be finish-
ed within a month. Attached to these hos-
pitals will be auxiliary buildings for kitchen
baths ete. Each of these hospitals contains a
big hall and six rooms with 25 beds. To the
women's hospital is annexed a maternity, and
a clinic, while a pharmacy and laboratory are
attached to the hospitals.

Now besides the above mentioned buildings
there is yet to be built according to the ori-
ginal plan another, to match in style and
proportion, the establishement proper and in
that case the Direction will stand in the middle
His Excellency has solicited His Majesty's
permission to continue levying the head tax
to raise the funds necessary for the continnuation
of the scheme, and the Imperial sanction is
said to have been granted. Surrounding the
central group of buildings is a large park 150
meters long and 155 meters wide, with four
ponds and jets in the middle, five elegant
kiosks and a profusion of spouts to be fixed
at intervals of 20 meters. This park is to be
open for the public, and will, indeed, be the
only on Fridays and Sundays with certain
restrictions.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p:
The Moss liner "Menepthah" sailed from
Liverpool on Sunday last and is due here
about the 6th prox. with passengers, mails, and
general cargo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p:
Mr. Gould, H.B.M.'s Consul General at
Alexandria, arrived this morning by the S.S.
"Caledonia."

Mr. and Mrs. Clarke Shaw have returned
from Mount Troodos.

The appointment, of Col. Milne, D.S.O., Com-
manding the Royal Field Artillery at Brighton,
to command the Royal House Artillery in
Egypt, has been cancelled.

Captain W. H. V. Darell, 3rd battalion
Coldstream Guards, has been granted leave of
absence from the 2nd prox. till November 4.

Mohamed Aly Bey, son of Ezzat Pasha
Elabbed, has been appointed Turkish ambas-
sador in Washington.

Among those who arrived this morning from
Europe by the M.M. "Orenoque" were Mr.
Littlewood, Mr. Arcache, Neguib Bey el
Ghindi, Mr. G. Brook, Dr. Milton, Daninos
Pasha. Mr. and Mrs. Escoffier, Mr. Roe, Mr.
Clarke, Mr. D. Tweedie, Mrs: and Miss
Laroche. and Mr. H. Hall.

div.head: HOTEL-CASINO SAN STEFANO IS NOW OPEN
div.p:
Will be open during Winter.
Reduced Prices

div.head: Circlaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES

div.p:
Le Caire, Lundi 23 Septembre.
Le taux de l'escompte libre 4 Londres est
renseigne invarie a 3 7/8 pour cent.
Au Stock Exchange, les Consolides anglais
ont hausse hier de 1/8 a 82 3/8. L'Unifiee a
garde son cours de 101 3/4. La National Bank
a continue sa hausse A 20 7/8, la Daira egale-
ment a 12 7/8 et l'Agricole est restee invariee
a 8 3/8, ainsi que la Delta Light a 9 7/8.

A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a encore
gegne 5 francs a 702, la Banque d'Athenes a
3 francs a 115 et les Lots Tures ont
hausse de 1 franc a 167.

Ici, comme le faisaient prevoir les depeches
de Londres et Paris recues samedi dernier,
signalant une hausse subite'des valeurs egyp-
tiennes surces deux places, notre marche a
auivi sans trop se faire prier. Que cette hansse
provienne, comme on l'a dit, d'une decision da
Cabinet anglais dintervenir en faveur dn
Credit de l'Egypte, c'est tres possible, mais
nous pensons que lannonce d'une recolte co-
tonnitre tres superieure 4 celle de lannee der-
niere y est pas etrangere aussi bien que les
taux d'interets eleves fournis par les titres
egyptiens aux cours actuels.

Quoi quil en soit, la seance a ete ce matin
tres animee des le debut avec tendance a la
hausse. Le nombre des transactions aurait
pu etre tres superieur si les vendeurs escomp-
tant une continuation dela hausse, avaient
fait defaut, en fin de seance.

Le' mouvement s'est porte surtout sur les
gros titres, quoique nos valeurs locales aient
profite largement des bonnes dispositions du
marche, Neanmoins pour ces dernieres, |effet
de la reprise ne se fera sentir fortement que si
les cours des valeurs dirigeantes se maintien-
nent, ce quil y a tout lien de croire.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na-
tional Bank hausse de 7/16 a 20 13/16. LA-
gricole la suit plus modestement a 8 3/16-1/4.
La Banque dOrient avance a 120-121, et la
Cassa di Sconto egalement a 40-41. Le Comp-
toir Financier remonte a 25/8. La fondatenr
H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd. a cloture en
nouvelle hansse a 6.

Le Delta Light se consolide a 9 3/4. Les
Jouissances Eaux du Caire se ressaisissent a
193.Les Eaux de Tantah tombent a 6. La Daira
Sanieh est en forte avance a 12 13/16-7/8. Le
Credit Foncier influence par son cours de Paris
s'inscrit avec 10 francs de hausse a 695. Les
obligations anciennes suivent a 300 et les nou-
velles a 255. LAllotment progresse a 2 3/8 et
la fondateur a P.T. 64-65. Les Entreprises Im-
mobilitres et Travaux sont fermes a 23/8,
tandis que leur part remonte a P.T. 44. LAn-
glo-American Nile est plus soutenue a 2 7/16
et les Tramways dAlexandrie fiechissent a 142
action et 298 la part.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, peu d'affaires;
seules les Upper Egypt salourdissent a 2 3/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, La Delta Land
tres animee, sinseriten nonvelle plus value a
1 13/16. Les Egyptian Estates se relevent a
0 5/811/16. La New Egyptian est tres de-
mandee 4 13/9. Les Markets sont realisees A
28/3.

On nous ecrit dAlexandrie:
"A part les ventes aox encheres pour le
compte de la Bourse and Banking et de quel-
ques particuliers, nous savons detres bonne
source quaucune grosse liquidation a, en lien
comme on sest plu a le dire depuis quelques
jours.

"Il est meme certain qu'il ne sen produira
pas d'ici longtemps, et que dfit-on recourir a
ce moyen, on nee le ferait qua la derniere extre-
mite et de facon a troubler le moins possible
le cours normal des transactions.

"D'ailleura, linteret des etablissements qui
detiennent des portefeuilles en souffrance
est pas de brusquer les choses, mais bien de
temporiser pour risquer le moins."

On nous signale de Paris une demande tres
forte sur les titres du Canal de Suez, motivee
par la plus-value constante des recettes qui
depasse a l'heure actuelle 4 millions ; de ce
fait, il y aurait aucun prelevement a faire sur
la reserve speciale pour maintenir le dividende
de laction a 141 francs. Lan dernier il avait
ete preleve 3,800,000 pour parfaire cette
repartition.

A la reunion des creanciers de la Bourse
and Banking, il a ete constate que le montant
de leurs avances tait de 86,000 livres. Dautre
part, lactif realisable etant evalue a 44 1/2 %,
il en resulte que les actionnaires seront pro-
bablement ecartes de toute repartition. II se
confirne que la liquidation ce ferait judiciaire-
ment.

Jeudi dernier a eu lieu une deuxieme
assemblee de la Building Land, la premiere
ayant pu avoir lieu faute de quorum, A
l'effet de decider le rachat de 12,500 actions
au-dessous du pair, avec les sommes encaissees
au fur et a mesure des echeances.

Cette proposition a ete adoptee, ainsi que
la creation eventuelle de 75,000 livres dobliga-
tions.

Les modifications aux statuts proposees par
le Conseil ont ete venvoyees A une autre
assemblee.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p:
Aujourd'hui apres midi a 5h.30, grand concert
sur la terrasse du Casino, donne par l'excellent
orchestre Bracale. Ces concerts, qui attirent
toujours tant de promeneurs, continueront
jusque vers le 15 du mois prochain. Le casino
restera ouvert tout l'hiver et la direction nous
promet de nous offrir pas mal de distractions
Il sera aussi emis desabonnements d'hiver, a
dater du 15 Octobre au 15 Mai, a raison de
P.T. 200 le billet de famille et P.T. 100 l'a-
bonnement simple.

div.head:
THE CASABLANCA SITUATION.
CAPITULATION OF TRIBES
MOULEY HAFID'S MOVEMENTS

div.p:
300 more men of the Foreign Legion will
sail from Orain for Casablanca to-day.

A manifesto has been issued here urging
the French and Spanish workers to make a
common campaign against the Moorish expedi-
tion and to stop the slaughter. (Reuter )

The march extended twelve miles from the
town : the troops carried three days rations
with them - the Arab camp has been burned.
(Reuter )

The Sultan, Abdel Aziz, has arrived at
Rabat. Muley Hafid has left Marrakesh with
6000 men and guns, going in the direction of
Casablanca, bat it is uncertain whether his
objective is General Drude or Abdel Aziz.
(Reuter)

The tribes of Oulad Zeyan and Zenata have
capitulated. They must deliver up the authors
of the outrage of the 30th July and provide
hostages. Mouley Hafid left Marakesh on the
19th inst and marched on Casablanca. They
do not knowifhe is marching against Abd el
Aziz or General Drude. ( Havas)

The Sultan Abd el Aziz has arrived at Rabat.
( Havas)

div.head:
NEW FRENCH CRUISER.
ANTIMILITARISTS' DISGRACEFUL
CONDUCT.

div.p:
The "Edgar Quinet," the largest cruiser in
the navy, bas been launched here. The anti-
militarists on the occasion sang the "Inter-
nationale" songs and hooted the officers
present. ( Reuter )

div.head:
THE PERSIAN SITUATION.
PARLIAMENTARY AGITATION.
ANGLO-RUSSIAN CONVENTION.

div.p:
According to news received from Teheran
the situation has perceptibly become worse.
Since the murder of the Grand Vizir Parlia-
ment is apparently seeking to get all power
and is interfering with every branch of adminis
tration.

The ratifications of the Anglo-Russian
convention were exchanged here to-day.
( Reuter )

div.head:
AMERICA AND THE PHILIPPINES,
ADMIRAL DEWEY'S VIEWS

div.p:
Admiral Dewey strongly condemns the agi-
tation in favour of selling the Philippines. He
says if the Islands passed over to Japan the
latter would command every gateway in the
Orient and completely shut out America both
commercially and strategically. The abandon-
ment would mean that the United-States
would cease to have a diplomatic voice in
Eastern affairs. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE HOME RAILWAYS.
MR. BELL'S ADVICE.

div.p:
Mr. Bell, addressing railwaymen at Cardift
said that they must show the Companies that
they meant business, but even if the ballot
favoured a strike another diplomati attempt
would be made before the strike would be
declared. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE ANATOLIAN RAILWAY.
THE GALATA BRIDGE.

div.p:
Irades have been published relative to the
laying down of a double track of line of the
Haidar Pasha Railway, (Anatolia) and the
construction of the Galata bridge The con-
struction of this bridge which, as is known,
has been entrusted to the Augsbourg Machine
Factory and the Nuremberg Machine Con-
struction Society, will shortly be commenced
since the expenses have been assured by the
irade which has just been published. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE YEMEN SITUATION.
IMPROVEMENT AT SANAA.

div.p:
According to the latest information the sit-
uation at Sanaa has greatly improved. The
rebels have withdrawn, probably owing to the
return of the Yemen mission from Constanti-
nople. Great relief is felt in Turkish circles.
(Reuter)

A meeting of Ambassadors held here was
unanimous regarding the necessity for judicial
reform in Macedonia. The Porte's scheme, se-
veral particulars of which may possibly be in-
corporated in the Powers' own scheme, was
favourably considered. ( Reuter)

The Khedive has postponed his departure
for Egypt till Wednesday in order to attend
the celebration of the Sultan's birthday.
( Reuter)

German Colonial Secretary, Herr
Dernburg, has arrived here en route for a tour
in German East Africa. ( Reuter)

M.M. Barthon, Thomson, and Briand have
inaugurated the new entrance to the harbour.
( Havas)

7 workmen and a girl have been shot here
untried, for complicity in the murder of a
leading manufacturer. ( Reuter)

div.head: THE AMERICA CUP DEFENDER.
div.p:
Mr. Nathaniel G. Herreshoff, the designer
of America Cup defenders of the past fourteen
years, has held conferences within the last
few weeks with Commodore E. D. Morgan, of
the New York Yacht Club, who managed the
Columbia in 1901, and with Captain C. Oliver
Iselin, who had charge of the Reliance in 1903.
Mr. Herreshoff has also taken part in a cruise
of the New York Yacht Club, in the course of
which he had interviews with many promi
nent yachtsmen. From an authoritative source
(says Reuter) it is now learned that Mr.
Herreshoff has completed preliminary designs
for a 90ft. sloop yacht on the lines of the
new American rnles of measurement. The yacht
will be an enlarged Avenger, a boat which has
won nearly every contest for which she has
entered this year, and which is looked upon
as an ideal boat, especially in light weather.

335 BRANCHES.

div.head: PERSIAN POLITICS.
THE SITUATION IN THE SOUTH.
div.p:
In March last I pointed out, says a cor-
respondent to the "Globe" the seriousness of
the problem which would face the Majlis, or
National Assembly, in controlling the affairs
ofSouthern Persia, which promised develop-
ments along certain lines as. these develop-
ments have since that date taken place, to the
consternation. of the Assembly, I give a brief
account of the leading features of the situation
as it stands to-day.

Unlike the involved politics of most parts of
Persia, those of Fars are comparatively simple,
as two factors control the situation; to the ex-
clusion of minor parties. These are the two
great nottiad tribes of the Qashqai and Arab.
The former has both its summer and winter
quarters in Fars, journeying in May to the
highlands of Kam Firuz and Western Fars,
and returning in October via the Shiraz valley
to the lowlands of Shapur, and the sonthern
plainlainds about Lar and Darab. The Arabs,
however, whose native soil is Persian Arabistan
the that flat country about the head of the
Persien Gulf--take a more or less direct line
easterly by way of Bebbehan to a district
farther north of Shiraz, that of Dehbid, a fertile
plain some 7,500 feet above sea level. As in
the case of the Qashquai, they set out for the
higlands in May, to return in October and
November for the winter. Both tribes are im-
mensely wealthy, considered by Persian stan-
dards, owning extensive herds of cattle and
growing their corn upon land for the use and
irrigation of which they pay nothing. Consider-
able revenue also accrues to them from the
sale of the rugs and carpets for which Fars is
celebrated, and which are manufactured ex-
clusively by the women in their tents.

The Qashqai, which is a tribe of Turkish
origin, owns allegiance to its own leaders, the
hereditary Il-Khani, the present head bearing
the title Saulat ud Douleh, â€œThe Fury of the
Empire,â€ who as a rule moves with the tribe,
and who is personally responsible fur its good
behaviour and regular payment of such taxes
as the Government can induce them to render.

As has been the case with every semi-
independent tribe, past Governments have not
failed to endeavour to break their power by
splitting them into factions, which policy has
at times succeeded, byt which, while leaving
the tribe weaker that it might otherwise have
been, has engendered a hatred of Rersians and
their methods. They are now fairly well united
under the Saulat ud Douleh, who has succeed-
ed in temporarily silencing his brother the
Zargham ud Douleh, whose following has been
considerably reduced within the last few
months.

The Arab tribes have no such hereditary
leader, and while they have their sectional
headmen, they have been accustomed to ac-
knowledge allegiance to a leader who has re-
ceived his appointment from the Government
Such leadership hag been and is a rich prize
for which to scheme, for it confers great power
and wealth uponan astute man who under-
stands how to treat the nomads. For years
they were under the leadership of Amir Agha
Khan, Mansur us Saltaneh--a native of Shiraz,
whose father had been colonel of the Arab
regiment--long since disbanded. The Qavvam
ul Mulk, also a Shirazi, who was then rising to
the power he has possessed for so many years
in Fars, succeeded in procuring his dismissal,
and gained the post himself. Bad as his rule
has been, he has taken pains to understand the
people over whom he has given full control,
and has gained their preference for him over
any other. His two sons have been brought up
in intimacy with the tribesmen, and while his
fighting power was thus increased, the Qavvam
ul Mulk steadily pursned his course of purchas-
ing land and controlling the local affairs of
Shiraz, which latter he achieved by securing
the appointment of mayor ot the town for his
elder son, the Salar us Sultan.

In the autumn of 1905, after the late Shah's
second son, Prince Shaa us Saltaneh, had been
expelled fromShiraz by the infuriated population,
urged on by the Mayor, the Government, fearful
of leaving there so powerfula personage, induced
the Qavvam ul mulk to accompany the Prince
to Teheran, giving pledges that he would stand
in no danger. Confident that his sons could
manage the position, and by threats, if neces-
sary, of revolution, sufficiently protect him,
he agreed, and found himself a prisoner almost
immediately after his arrival at the capital.

This bold step on the part of the Govern-
ment was rendered possible by the treachery
of s man in whom the Qavvam ul Mulk had
for years placed the greatest confidence, one
Mirza Hussein Khan Kavari, at whose back
was the well-armed population of his district
of Kavar, near Shiraz. This individual fell
victim to the promises of spoil held out by
the Government, and deserting his former
chief, fled to a garden near Shiraz, where he
took up a fortified position. Later, when the
Qavvan ul Malk returned to Shiraz, deprived
of his control of the Arab tribe, Mirza Hussein
Khan, more commonly known as the Mu'
tamed ud Divan, proceeded to Teheran, where
he commenced a campaign of intrigue against
his former benefactor to such effect that the
younger son came to Teheran in the hope of
adjusting affairs. Thither he was followed by
his elder brother, and the old Qavvam ul Mulk
left alone in Shiraz, his properties unguarded,
and fearful of new treachery, made a piligrim-
age to Meshed, where he now remains.

Meanwhile the Nizam us Saltaneh, present
Governor of Shiraz, has announced to the
Arabs that their leader will henceforth be the
traitor Mu'tamed ud Divan, and the sons,
who still remain in Teheran, have protested
in vain against this appointment. Nor are
the troubles of the Qavvam ul Malk ended
here, for the Qashqai tribe, quick to take an

opportunity, are burning and destroying his
properties in Fars. The Arabs. themselves are
infuriated at the double dealing which has
robbed them of a family to whom they had
learned to look, and in protest are stopping
the posts and commencing a campaign of bri-
ealage in the district they ocoupy as sum-
mer quarters.

The sons of the Qavvam ul Mulk are doing
their best to take advantage of this display
of feeling, and while the Arabs around Dehbid
plunder and revolt, refusing to submit to the
rule of the Mu'tamed ad Divan, they are
joining handsâ€˜with Sheikh Fazlullah, a revo-
lutionary of increasing infiuence, whose aim
is to overthrow the Majlis by the methods of
anarchy.

The principal scene of trouble on and about
the main road has for the time being shifted
to the north of Shiraz, owing to the presence
there of the tribes, but in October they will
be moving again, and the Bushire-Shiraz road
will become the centre of disturbance. Not
that it is quiet now ; on the contrary, the local
hill people and tribes are taking full advantage
of the confessed inability of the Majlis to
control them, engaging themselves in highway
robbery and petty warfare, which keeps the
country in a state of terror.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p:
Two officers of the 2nd Battalion Essex
Regiment--Captains C. 1. Ryan, and C. J. B.
Daubeny, have been selected for service with
the Khedive's army under the usual conditions.
The first named officer joined the gallant
"Pompadours" in February, 1897, and served
with the 2nd Battalion in the South
African War, earning the Queen's medal with
four clasps for the operations in Orange River
Colony, 1901-2, and Captain Daubeny, who
joined the regiment in 1896, served with the
Essex Regiment, and the 29th Battalion Mount-
ed Infantry, for which he received the Queen's
medal with four clasps.

Second Lieutenant D. French, Royal Dublin
Fusiliers, of the 1st Battalion, Alexandria, has
been advanced to the rank of full lieutenant.
He got his second lieutenancy in May, 1902,
and had an exceptionally long time to serve
for his second star.

Major S.C. Johuston, King's Own Scottish
Borderers, has gone on retired pay. He served
for nearly twenty years in the old 25th, and
was with it in the operations of 1889 on the
Soudan Frontier (medal, and Khedive's star),
and he was adjutant ofa battalion of Imperial
Yeomanry in the South African War, 1902
(Queen's medal with two clasps). The vacancy
has been filled by the promotion of Captain
A. G. Fraser, adjutant of the Galloway Rifles.
Major Fraser, who now returns to regimental
daty, has served alittle over nineteen years
for his major's crown, and he has a good war
record to his credit, including the Chitral
Relief Expedition, 1895 (medal with clasp) ;
the Soudan Campaign, 1898, whilst employed
with the Egyptian Army, and was orderly
officer to Major General Hunter at the battle
of Atbara ; and was afterwards through the
operations at Gedaref as base commandant
(mentioned in despatches, medal with clasp,
British medal, and 4thclass Medjidie). He
was with the 1st Battalion of the King's Own
in South Africa, sharing in the fighting in the
Transvaal (Queen's medal with clasps).

A new buoy shackle, designed by Lieutenant
D.J. Munro, assistant to the commander of
Sheerness Dockyard, is ordered to be issued to
six torpedo boat destroyers for experimental
purposes. The shackle has been designed to
overcome the difficulty experienced by scouts,
torpedo gun boats, torpedo boat destroyers,
and torpedo boats in shackling on to a large
buoy, and it is small enough to take the
anchor shackle on a buoy. The shackle pin is
attached to the shackle by a keeper chain, and
cannot be lost overboard, and the pin is secured
by a special ring, obviating the use of screws,
forelocks, or any of the ordinary methods of
securing the pins of shackles.

Sanction has been given for the employment
of Brevet-Colonel J E. Gough, V.C., A.D.C. as
Inspector-General of the King's African Rifles.
The advancement of Colonel Gough, who is at
present serving on the General Staff at Head-
quarters of the Irish command, has been as
rapid as his carver has been distinguished. He
joined the Rifle Brigade in 1892 as a Second
Lieutenant, in which he now holds the
regimental rank of Captain, and he saw a good
deal of active campaigning during the first ten
years of his service. In 1896-7 he took part in
the expedition against. Chikusi and Chilwa in
British Central Africa, and was present at the
battle of Khartoum in 1898. In the South
African War he took an active part in the
defence of Ladysmith and the subsequent
operations of the Natal Army under Sir Red-
vers Buller (brevit majority). Subsequently he
was employed as a special Service Officer in
the Somaliland operations of 1902-8 (Victoria
Cross and brevet of Lieutenant-Colonel). His
selection tor the post of Inspector General of
the King's African Rifles, at 35 years of age,
follows closely upon his recent appointment as
Aide-de-Camp to the King, together with
promotion to the brevet rank of Colonel.

div.head:
JOINTS SHAPELESS WITH
RHEUMATISM.
div.p:
The Patient, a Man of 75, also Suf-
fered from Lumbago, Sciatica, Diz-
ziness and Pains in the Head,
Urinary Disorders, and Gravel.

Mr. William Davis, 96, Brereton Road,
Rugeley, England, says :-"I am 75 years old,
but I am not too old to have found out how
good Doan's Backache Kidney Pills are. They
have brought me great comfort, and I can
highly recommend them.

"My work has always exposed me to the
weather, and many a time I have got wet
through to the skin. In my own mind I have
no doubt that this is what brought on the
sciatica and lumbago from which I first suffered
12 years ago. Iwas confined to my bed for a
long time, and the agony I underwent was
terrible. I also had rheumatism and my joints
were shapeless with it.

Occasionally my head was so bad that I was
light headed ; many atime I have come over so
dizzy that, but for some handy support, I
should have fallen. The kidney secretions were
scalding in passing and full of gravel.

"After trying all manner of 'cures,' and
spending pounds on doctor's medicine, without
getting any relief, I went under hospital
treatment, yet I could not get well.

"Ihad read a good deal about Doan's Backache
Kidney Pills, and my friends had urged me to
try them, so at last I got some, and by the time
the first box was finished I was certainly better.
Encouraged, I went on with the medicine,
and now I can truthfully say that it is many a
long year since I felt so well as I do to-day. I
can take quite a long walk without exhaustion
--a thing I had not been able to do for years
before I began with Doan's Backache Kidney
Pills."

Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all
chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box.
